title: About
text:
Maria Tsagiopoulou
Co-founder / CEO, Biologist / Bioinformatician
Dr. Maria Tsagiopoulou is a postdoctoral researcher at the National Centre for Genomic Analysis in Spain, one of Europe’s largest Genome Centres. She has more than 9 years of experience in analyzing and interpreting omics data to identify patterns in the genome, transcriptome, and epigenome levels that correlate with the pathogenesis and the evolution of diseases. Her research includes aspects of multiple disciplines, with a particular focus on immunology and oncology, utilizing bioinformatics and machine learning approaches to analyze omics data. Her expertise lies at the intersection of bioinformatics and deep knowledge of biology, enabling effective collaboration with researchers across various life science domains and clinicians. She has a comprehensive understanding of controlled vocabularies in biology, medicine, and computer sciences, facilitating efficient interdisciplinary communication
      










Konstantinos Kyritsis
Co-founder / COO, Bioinformatician
Dr. Kyritsis is working as a postdoctoral researcher at the Institute of Applied Biosciences in the Centre for Research and Technology Hellas (INAB/CERTH). His research interests are currently focused on studying molecular mechanisms and unveiling patterns of functional significance using machine learning algorithms to omics data. Furthermore, his interests include developing bioinformatic tools and pipelines for integrating and visualizing heterogenous bio-data.















Nikos Pechlivanis
Co-founder / CTO, Bioinformatics Engineer
Nikos Pechlivanis works as a Bioinformatics engineer at the Institute of Applied Biosciences in the Centre for Research and Technology Hellas. His research interests focuses on studying machine learning algorithms and computational techniques with respect to their corresponding applications on genomic and meta-genomic data. In addition to his research, he supports open source/science principles, in support of reusability and accessibility of scientific results.
      









Fotis Psomopoulos
Co-founder/ CSO, ML engineer & Research Manager
Dr. Fotis Psomopoulos is a Senior Researcher (Associate Professor level) at the Institute of Applied Biosciences (INAB), at the Centre for Research and Technology Hellas (CERTH), in Thessaloniki Greece. His research interests lie at the intersection of Bioinformatics and Machine Learning, primarily working on the design and implementation of data mining algorithms for knowledge extraction from large datasets in Life Sciences. He is the Training Coordinator of ELIXIR-GR, a member of the ELIXIR Training Platform Executive Committee, and a member of the EOSC Association Research Careers, Recognition and Credit Task Force. Finally, he is a strong advocate of FAIR and Open Science; as applied in research software and machine learning in particular. He is a co-author of the Open Science Training Handbook and the Greek National Plan for Open Science, and is leading the ELIXIR Software Best Practices group, with a notable outcome the ELIXIR Software Management Plan, and the RDA FAIR for Machine Learning Interest Group.

title: Services
text:
Omics Data Analysis

Omics data analysis is a multidisciplinary field that involves the study and interpretation of various biological data types such as genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and others. These approaches provide comprehensive insights into the molecular components of biological systems and their functions.
4omics offers services for key omics data analysis areas:

Genomics: Genomics is the study of an organism’s complete set of DNA, including all its genes and non-coding regions. Genomic data analysis involves tasks such as DNA sequencing, variant calling, genome assembly, and annotation.
Transcriptomics: Transcriptomics focuses on the analysis of RNA molecules, particularly messenger RNA (mRNA), to understand gene expression patterns and regulation. Techniques like RNA-Seq and microarray analysis are used to measure transcript levels.
Proteomics: Proteomics involves the study of all proteins in a biological sample. Analysis includes protein identification, quantification, and functional characterization. Mass spectrometry is a common tool for proteomics data analysis.
Metabolomics: Metabolomics aims to characterize the small molecules (metabolites) present in a biological sample. It provides insights into metabolic pathways and how they respond to various conditions. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and mass spectrometry are often used in metabolomics research.
Epigenomics: Epigenomics examines changes in gene activity and expression that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Analysis includes DNA methylation, histone modification, and chromatin structure studies.
Metagenomics: Metagenomics is the study of genetic material recovered directly from environmental samples, which may contain complex mixtures of microorganisms. It’s widely used in microbiome research and involves the analysis of 16S rRNA, shotgun sequencing, and taxonomic classification.

Omics data analysis typically follows a series of steps:

Data Acquisition: Generate or obtain raw data through techniques like DNA sequencing, microarray experiments, or mass spectrometry.
Preprocessing: Clean and preprocess the data to remove noise, correct for technical biases, and normalize data if needed.
Data Analysis: Perform various analyses, such as differential expression analysis, pathway analysis, clustering, and data visualization.
Integration: Integrate data from different omics layers to gain a holistic understanding of biological processes.
Interpretation: Interpret the results in the context of the biological question under investigation. This may involve identifying biomarkers, understanding regulatory networks, or discovering new biological insights.
Validation: Experimentally validate key findings from the analysis using wet lab experiments.
Visualization: Communicate the results through scientific publications, reports, or presentations.

Omics Data Analysis

The emphasis on the principles of FAIR data and Green Computing in your services is commendable and reflects a commitment to responsible and sustainable data management and IT practices. Here’s a breakdown of the assessment and applications of FAIR and Green Computing in your services:

FAIR Data:


Findable: In the context of FAIR data, “findable” means that your services make it easy for users to discover and locate relevant data. This can be achieved by implementing metadata standards, unique identifiers, and a structured organization of data repositories.
Accessible: Accessibility ensures that data is available to users when needed. It involves providing clear access points, using standardized data formats, and maintaining proper data documentation to help users understand and use the data.
Interoperable: Interoperability is about ensuring that your data can be integrated with other data sources or systems seamlessly. This requires adhering to data standards, using common ontologies, and providing well-documented APIs for data access.
Reusable: Data should be reusable, which means it is not only understandable but also well-documented. This allows users to apply the data in various contexts. Proper data versioning and citing should also be encouraged to enhance data traceability and attribution.


Green Computing:

Green Computing focuses on reducing the environmental impact of computing and data storage practices. It promotes energy-efficient and sustainable IT operations. In the context of your services:

Data Center Efficiency: Implement energy-efficient practices in your data centers, such as using advanced cooling systems, optimizing server utilization, and adopting virtualization to reduce hardware requirements.
Renewable Energy: Consider using renewable energy sources, such as solar or wind power, to run your data centers. This significantly reduces the carbon footprint associated with data processing.
Data Storage Optimization: Use data deduplication, compression, and efficient data storage strategies to reduce the amount of physical storage required and decrease energy consumption.
Cloud Computing: Embrace cloud computing, which allows for dynamic resource allocation and scalability, ensuring resources are used efficiently and only as needed.
E-Waste Management: Promote responsible disposal and recycling of electronic waste generated by your services. This includes the proper disposal of old hardware and recycling of components.
Green Software Development: Encourage sustainable software development practices, such as optimizing code for energy efficiency and developing applications that consume fewer resources.

Incorporating FAIR data principles ensures that your data is well-organized, discoverable, and reusable, which is critical for scientific research, data sharing, and collaboration. Embracing Green Computing practices aligns with environmental responsibility and sustainability, reducing the environmental footprint of data storage and processing.
Promoting these principles not only benefits the environment but also enhances the value of your services, making them attractive to organizations and researchers who prioritize responsible data management and sustainable computing practices. It can also be a strong selling point in today’s environmentally conscious world.

Experimental Design and Grant Writing

Experimental design and grant writing are essential components of the scientific research process, particularly in academia and research institutions.
Here’s an overview of both aspects that 4omics can be involved in your project:

Experimental Design:

Experimental design is the process of planning and structuring experiments to ensure that they are robust, scientifically sound, and capable of generating meaningful results. A well-designed experiment minimizes bias, increases the likelihood of obtaining valid data, and ensures efficient resource utilization. Key elements of experimental design include:

Research Question: Clearly define your research question or hypothesis that you want to address with the experiment.
Experimental Variables: Identify the independent (manipulated) and dependent (measured) variables. Consider potential confounding variables and how to control for them.
Study Population: Determine the target population or sample for your study. Ensure that it is representative and adequately sized to detect meaningful effects.
Experimental Controls: Design control groups or conditions to compare with the treatment group. Controls help eliminate spurious results and isolate the effect of the independent variable.
Randomization: Use randomization to assign subjects or samples to treatment groups. Randomization helps minimize selection bias.
Blinding: Implement blinding, where possible, to prevent biases in data collection and analysis. Single-blind and double-blind methods can be used.
Replication: Consider how many times you will replicate your experiments to ensure the reliability of results.
Statistical Analysis: Plan the statistical methods you will use to analyze the data. This includes sample size calculations, hypothesis testing, and data visualization.
Ethical Considerations: Ensure your experiment complies with ethical guidelines and obtains the necessary approvals, especially when involving human or animal subjects.
Resources: Assess the resources required, including equipment, personnel, and budget, to conduct the experiment.


Grant Writing:

Grant writing is the process of preparing applications for research funding from government agencies, private foundations, or other institutions. A successful grant proposal persuades the funding agency that your research is valuable, feasible, and deserving of financial support. Key components of grant writing include:

Proposal Structure: Follow the guidelines provided by the funding agency regarding the structure and content of the proposal. Common sections include an abstract, introduction, literature review, research plan, timeline, budget, and references.
Research Plan: Detail your research objectives, methodology, experimental design, and data analysis plan. Clearly articulate how your work will advance knowledge in your field.
Budget Justification: Provide a detailed budget, including personnel salaries, equipment costs, supplies, and other expenses. Justify the budget by explaining how each cost is necessary for the research.
Impact and Significance: Describe the potential impact of your research on the field, society, or industry. Explain the significance of the problem you’re addressing.
References: Cite relevant literature to support the importance of your research and demonstrate that you are well-informed about the field.
Collaborations: Highlight any collaborations, partnerships, or institutional support that will strengthen your research project.
Timeline: Create a timeline outlining the major milestones and expected completion dates for your research.
Peer Review: Seek feedback from colleagues or mentors to improve the proposal’s clarity, coherence, and persuasiveness.
Compliance: Ensure that your proposal complies with the specific requirements and submission deadlines of the funding agency.
Editing and Proofreading: Carefully edit and proofread your proposal to eliminate errors and enhance its professionalism.
